description: Move you camera until white dots will display in your screen. Touch at any white dots to start your learning!
Welcome back, class!  We've explored the actors (biotic and abiotic) on the
ecosystem stage. Now, let's delve into the fascinating relationships between them!
Ecosystems are a complex web of interactions, where organisms rely on each other
and their environment in various ways. Today, we'll explore some of the most
common ecological relationships:
Mutualism:  This is a win-win situation for both parties involved!  Two different
organisms live together in a close association, where each benefits from the other.
For example, Clownfish and sea anemones. Clownfish live among the stinging
tentacles of sea anemones, which offer protection from predators. In return,
clownfish chase away predators of the anemone and may even attract food with their bright colors.
Commensalism:  Here, one organism benefits from the relationship, while the
other is neither helped nor harmed.  It's kind of a one-sided friendship.
For example, Barnacles clinging to a whale's skin. The barnacles benefit by getting
a free ride and access to food particles in the water, while the whale is largely unaffected.
Another ecological relationship is Predation, this is a survival-of-the-fittest scenario!
One organism (the predator) hunts, kills, and eats another organism (the prey).
Example: A lion hunting a zebra. The lion benefits by obtaining food (energy).
Competition: This is a battle for resources!  Organisms compete for things like
food, water, space, and sunlight.  Competition can be fierce and can determine
which organisms survive and reproduce successfully.
Example: Two species of trees competing for sunlight in a forest. The trees with
better access to sunlight will grow taller and have a higher chance of survival.
Decomposition:  This is nature's recycling process!  Decomposers, like bacteria
and fungi, break down dead organisms and waste products, returning nutrients to
the ecosystem.  They're the unsung heroes of the ecosystem!
Parasitism:  This is a freeloading situation! One organism (the parasite) benefits
by living on or in another organism (the host), harming the host in the process.
Example: A tick feeding on the blood of a dog. The tick benefits by obtaining
nutrients from the dog's blood, while the dog can suffer from irritation and disease
These are just some of the many ecological relationships found in ecosystems. The
way organisms interact with each other and their environment determines the overall
health and stability of the ecosystem.  A change in one part of the ecosystem can
have cascading effects on other parts.
You guys did a good job,Thank you for listening, see you on our next lesson!
